https://studio.code.org/s/how-ai-works-2.long_instructions:
# WeTube Video Recommendations (Beta) WeTube is a new media website with a unique way of finding videos: **it's entirely by recommendations**. There's no way to search for or bookmark videos - the only content you see is based on the people you like and subscribe to. Based on the subscription, you‚Äôll see videos from these content creators and other videos they like and recommend. **Do This:** - Press the orange Run button underneath the app window to start the app. Choose a content creator to follow. Each content creator has a small biography to help you decide who to follow. - Once you've chosen a person, check out the videos that are automatically recommended to you. - If you'd like, try a few other content creators to see which videos they recommend.
üîé Click here to read more about Alex

Alex loves spending time outdoors, exploring nature, and going on thrilling adventures. He frequently reviews comic books and analyzes superheroes. He‚Äôs fascinated with cowboys and the "old west", frequently wearing cowboy hats in videos. His friends describe him as a kind, fun-loving, and creative spirit.

A Few of their most popular videos:

  • Top 3 hiking trails in your area
  • Why the Green Lantern is the best comic hero of all time
  • How to make Sundubu at home
üîé Click here to read more about Sofia

Sofia spends time expressing herself through arts and crafts projects. Her most popular videos show her finding inspiration in nature and working with various materials to create unique pieces. She also has a love of books and enjoys finding a quiet place to read and escape the world. She also posts videos showing how to upcycle materials to create unique jewelry and accessories from different materials. Her friends describe her as down-to-earth, creative, and compassionate.

A Few of their most popular videos:

  • Variations on Duct Tape Wallets
  • Harry Potter or Percy Jackson: which is better?
  • How to spot gemstones in your neighborhood
üîé Click here to read more about Aanya

Aanya creates content focused on science and technology - she built herself a makeshift laboratory and makerspace in her garage. She‚Äôs fascinated by the mysteries of the universe and uses science to try and uncover it. Some of her most popular videos are interviews with other scientists, or unboxing videos of the latest STEM gadget. Her friends describe her as ambitious, hands-on, and intellectual.

A Few of their most popular videos:

  • Baking soda and vinegar: what could go wrong?
  • WOW! Interview with a real-life rocket scientist
  • Low-fi beats while in the makerspace
üîé Click here to read more about Joseph

Joseph aspires to be a professional athlete and dedicates his content to how he and his idols work towards their dreams. He also has a strong sense of humor, with many videos showing pranks he plays on his friends or his favorite jokes. As part of his sense of humor, he has a an extensive collection of silly hats. His friends describe him as outgoing and playful most of the time, but also focused and serious during practice.

A Few of their most popular videos:

  • Mastering the free-throw shot in basketball
  • Why I‚Äôm not allowed near water balloons anymore
  • Gnocchi with Nona
üîé Click here to read more about Zara

Zara has a deep love for animals and dreams of becoming a veterinarian. Their adventurous spirit is drawn to the thrill of horror stories and movies, where they enjoy exploring the unknown. Their videos are equal parts cute animal videos and reactions to horror films and jump-scares. Their friends describe them as quirky, caring, and sometimes eerie.

A Few of their most popular videos:

  • üòçOtter is released back into water for the first time
  • Why modern ‚Äúhorror‚Äù movies aren‚Äôt actually very scary
  • Pyramids and UFOs? Let‚Äôs ask an expert

https://studio.code.org/s/how-ai-works-2.long_instructions:
# WeTube Video Recommendations (2.0) This version of the widget lets you combine weights to create your own custom recommendations. You can decide how much influence each content creator has over the videos you're recommended. Combine weights from different people to create your own custom video feed! **Do This:** - Use the widget to create a custom recommendation system using each of the content creators. - Combine their weights until you get a series of recommendations that you like and agree with. - Test multiple combinations before settling on one that you like

https://studio.code.org/s/how-ai-works-2.long_instructions:
# Written Voice Simulator

This app lets you create a brand new piece of writing based on a ‚Äúvoice‚Äù that has been written before. The term ‚Äúvoice‚Äù here does not refer to the sound of a spoken voice, but text that reads like an author's voice. Starting with a random word, the app gives you 5 options for  the next word based on the structure and probabilities of whatever short story, poem, song, or writing piece it's currently modeling. Use the example ‚Äúvoices‚Äù (written works), or add your own "voice" which could be from a well known work or some of your own writing!

## Do This

Press the orange Run button on the bottom of the app, then follow the prompts on your activity guide to explore this widget. Record your responses on your activity guide.

## Getting Help

More information about this widget is available in the [Written Voice Simulator User Guide][0], including steps on how to save your stories and load your own voices.
https://studio.code.org/s/how-ai-works-2.teacher_markdown: This activity is based on Botnik. Feel free to explore the real Botnik yourself, which trained on more words and has more options.

I18n_HAIW23L4.label3_2: Give your save file a name
I18n_HAIW23L4.label5_3: Copy / Paste or type  the words you want to create a model based on below
I18n_HAIW23L4.label1_5: Choose the Save file you want to load from the dropdown below
I18n_HAIW23L4.promptStory21: Please enter a name to save your story under
I18n_HAIW23L4.promptVoiceId: Please give the voice a name
I18n_HAIW23L4.promptVoiceRaw: Please enter text for the new voice

https://studio.code.org/s/how-ai-works-2.long_instructions:
# Eliza

Eliza was the name of a program that modeled a therapist who  encourages clients to talk. Eliza did not learn from a lot of text like a Large Language Model. Instead, it had ready-made responses for things people might say to it. It felt ‚Äúreal‚Äù to many.
This version of Eliza does not have very many responses pre-programmed, but will give you an idea of what talking to a chatbot that did not involve machine learning can be like.
https://studio.code.org/s/how-ai-works-2.teacher_markdown:
You may want students to figure out what Eliza's patterns are for themselves, but for your reference, here are the patterns:

-   No response
-   I feel
-   I felt
-   My \_\_\_\_ hurts
-   Anything with the term "mother" or "father"
-   Anything with "don't know"

https://studio.code.org/s/how-ai-works-2.long_instructions:
## Noisy Image Widget

# Overview

Explore what images look like with different amounts of noise added. Press the orange run button on the bottom of the app, then follow the instructions on your activity guide to see how noise affects what we see in an image, and how much of an image we can still detect even when noisy.

A [User Guide for the Noisy Image Widget][0] is provided if you have questions about how to use the widget.

# Explore the App - Noisy Image Widget

**Part 1) Start with the default image.** As a class, describe what details do you see at each of the values in the table on your activity guide

**Part 2) Choose your own image.** Choose noise levels where you expect someone else to...

-   A) Describe the whole picture
-   B) Know what it is, but not the details
-   C) Start to catch some details
-   D) Have no idea what this is a picture of

**Part 3) Diffusion Sketch.** Using your observations above, describe and / or sketch the image you used, pointing out key details you expect your partner to be able to find at different levels

**Part 4) Trade Image.**  Now show your partner the images at these noise levels. **Make sure to go in reverse order** - start with the "most noise" and gradually remove it. Write the details they see below.
https://studio.code.org/s/how-ai-works-2.teacher_markdown:
**How Realistic is this?** The spirit of this activity is authentic to a process used by Diffusion AI models, especially in relation to looking at "noisy images" and generating an image to remove the noise. You can see an example of this in the [Documentation for Midjourney][0] (an AI model that uses stable diffusion), where images start with a mostly blank canvas and gradually become more detailed and "in focus".

The actual method used to generate the noise has been simplified for this widget - it is not truly Gaussian noise (which is used in actual diffusion models), and is not truly done in "generations".

I18n_HAIW23L5.label1_1: Move the slider to add more or less generations of noise to the image

https://studio.code.org/s/how-ai-works-2.long_instructions:
# GAN Guessing Game

In this game the computer has created a rule for the kinds of passwords it accepts, based on the shapes and colors in the password. On your turn to guess, click the shapes to build a possible password. The computer will tell you if the password is accepted or not. Then, the computer will make a guess. You should click the button for whether you believe the computers guess followed the rule or not. The computer will tell you if you're right, and then it will be your turn again. Continue playing until you have guessed the rule!
https://studio.code.org/s/how-ai-works-2.teacher_markdown: The rule in this case is "must contain a red circle."

https://studio.code.org/s/how-ai-works-2.long_instructions:
## Cropping Widget

You are uploading photos to a social media site and need to crop them so the posts will upload quickly. 

Press the run button on the buttom of the app, then play around with the tool to see how it works. Try clicking on different areas or pressing the buttons on the screen.

### **Consider:** Which images are challenging for you to decide how to crop?

### **Discuss with a partner:**

-   Which images were challenging for you to decide how to crop? 
-   Which images did you and your partner crop the same? 
-   Which images did you and your partner crop differently?
